subject: JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: Sorry, I know very little about both of them until now. But it seems to me that I don t need necessarily JUnit test cases or suites if I use the new assert
messageBody:
Sorry, I know very little about both of them until now.

But it seems to me that I don't need necessarily JUnit test cases or
suites if I use the new assert statement in the code I write.

Of course it is better to have JUnit tests, but it has many side
effects in my eyes. Using assert statements would be a compromise.

I think I could use assert statements at the beginning of a method
and at the end, checking preconditions and postconditions.

By marking them somehow as preconditions and postconditions it should
theoretically be possible to automate generation of JUnit
tests/suites, including test data. The test data can be created
automatically by a tool which obeys the preconditions for that
purpose. Java Modelling Language seems to do exactly this. But I
think it is not adopted widely.

It seems that with JUnit I can only test methods which return a
value. Using JUnit will change the code one would normally create:
Because of JUnit you need to overwrite equals(), toString() and are
not allowed to use void return type if you want to test that method.

Using the assert statement instead I can also test classes which
return no value.

Besides all this problems whis JUnit is another one: Successful
JUnits tests are no guarantee that there are no bugs in the code I
read. This has to do with data chains. But I didn't understand this.

And I read that it is extremely time consuming to create test cases
for all possible cases.

The good thing about using assert statements would also be, that the
test is included in the method. So no extra coding of classes would
be requiered as with using JUnit. Everything is in one place, user
friendly.

Using assert statements will not force the developer to use a special
developing practice like testdriven development. He is free to
develop in his own style.

The synchronisation between test cases and methods to be tested would
is time consuming. And what happens if you change a method so that
preconditions or postconditions will become different? Will you
remember to change the JUnit to fit these changes? Or will you
sometimes forget? Error detecting is then twice as hard, since it can
originate in the test class or in the class to be tested. Thats a
point where assert statements are better in my eyes compared to JUnit.

So what do you think about my assumptions? I can be wrong because I'm
inexperienced with both of them.

Maybe I write complete nonsense. So please correct me if necessary.
The side effects of pure JUnit programming seem very large to me.
